prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UDSz39205 - C36-3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measurement of the continuum, CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) emission in the largest of the post-starburst targets (39205), diameter=0.56".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary science goal is to observe the continuum in Band 6, we therefore choose the TDM correlator mode with 40 km/s channels. This channel width is also sufficient to observe the CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) lines simultaneously (estimated line width 300 km/s) with the continuum. To achieve adequate signal-to-noise in the lines we will bin up to 100 km/s channels in post processing, which will allow us to detect the CI line at 6 sigma in each channel and CO(4-3) at 3 sigma (if the gas-to-dust ratio >110), with a minimum 3 channels over the line (assuming a line width of 300 km/s). From our high quality optical spectroscopy we anticipate small systematic uncertainties in the velocity of each galaxy of ~100 km/s, however this will not be an issue with our large spectral window width of 2300 km/s. Our correlator set-up yields data rates of 2.44 MB/s which is well within the limits stated in the ALMA technical handbook. We do not have any special requirements on calibration, bandpass accuracy, data rates or scheduling.

The half-light radii of our target in the rest-frame optical is 0.28". We therefore expect the dust and gas emission to be on similar scales, with a diameter of 0.56". We request a resolution of 0.5" (configuation C36-3) approximately match the extent of our sources. This will allow us to measure the size of the gas and dust emitting region using the uv distance as a function of amplitude (Chen et al. in prep). It is possible that the gas and dust sizes are slightly more or less than the extent of the beam, but the beam size can be tuned using different weightings in CASA. The largest angular scale of our target is 0.56", which is smaller than the maximum resolvable scale of 10.9" in configuration C36-3. We do not require use of the ACA.

Our primary science goal is to detect the rest-frame ~600um dust continuum in our post-starburst galaxies. Our targets are at z~1 so we will observe in Band 6 at ~230 GHz, which allows us to simultaneously observe the CI(1-0) line which is a good tracer of the diffuse molecular gas. The continuum RMS is estimated using a modified blackbody fit to the stacked 24-850um fluxes (with an additional mid-infrared powerlaw for hot dust, Casey 2012) assuming a dust emissivity index of beta=2, kappa=0.077 m^2kg^-1 and a fitted temperature of 25K. At rest-frame 600um the continuum flux density is 0.069mJy, so for a 5 sigma detection using a bandwidth of 7.5 GHz (assuming the source extends over one synthesised beam) we request an RMS of 13.7uJy. Our primary science goal is to measure the continuum, which drives our RMS request. However, we will also simultaneously observe the CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) lines to obtain information about the diffuse and dense gas content of PSBs. To estimate the intensity of CI(1-0) we estimated the molecular gas mass (6x10^9 Msun) from the stacked dust mass (6x10^7 Msun), assuming a G/D ratio of 100 for our post-starburst galaxies (Rowlands et al. 2015). The CI(1-0) line flux was estimated using equation 12 of Papadopoulos et al. (2004), assuming Q_10=0.35, X_CI=3x10^-5 and the Einstein A coefficient A_ul=7.93x10^-8 s^-1 (Papadopoulos & Geach 2012). We assume a line width of 300 km/s, yielding a peak CI line flux of 0.82 mJy. By integrating to the continuum RMS we expect to detect the CI(1-0) at 6 sigma siginificance in 100 km/s channels (assuming 3 channels over an expected line width of 300 km/s). If we do not detect the line this puts a hard upper limit on the molecular gas content of high redshift post-starburst galaxies. If the G/D ratio is >110 (expected for PSBs, see Rowlands et al. 2015) then we will detect CO(4-3) at >3 sigma in 100 km/s channels (assuming CO(4-3)/CO(1-0)~0.2, Carilli & Walter 2013).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UDSz46929 - C36-5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measurement of the continuum, CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) emission in the post-starburst target (46929) which does not fall in the frequency range of the other scince goals, diameter=0.24".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary science goal is to observe the continuum in Band 6, we therefore choose the TDM correlator mode with 40 km/s channels. This channel width is also sufficient to observe the CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) lines simultaneously (estimated line width 300 km/s) with the continuum. To achieve adequate signal-to-noise in the lines we will bin up to 100 km/s channels in post processing, which will allow us to detect the CI line at 6 sigma in each channel and CO(4-3) at 3 sigma (if the gas-to-dust ratio >110), with a minimum 3 channels over the line (assuming a line width of 300 km/s). From our high quality optical spectroscopy we anticipate small systematic uncertainties in the velocity of each galaxy of ~100 km/s, however this will not be an issue with our large spectral window width of 2300 km/s. Our correlator set-up yields data rates of 2.44 MB/s which is well within the limits stated in the ALMA technical handbook. We do not have any special requirements on calibration, bandpass accuracy, data rates or scheduling.

The half-light radii of our target in the rest-frame optical is 0.12". We therefore expect the dust and gas emission to be on similar scales, with a diameter of 0.24". We request a resolution of 0.2" (configuation C36-5) so that we will approximately match the extent of our sources. This will allow us to measure the size of the gas and dust emitting region using the uv distance as a function of amplitude (Chen et al. in prep). It is possible that the gas and dust sizes are slightly more or less than the extent of the beam, but the beam size can be tuned using different weightings in CASA. The largest angular scale of our target is 0.24", which is smaller than the maximum resolvable scale of 3.4" in configuration C36-5. We do not require use of the ACA.

Our primary science goal is to detect the rest-frame ~600um dust continuum in our post-starburst galaxies. Our targets are at z~1 so we will observe in Band 6 at ~230 GHz, which allows us to simultaneously observe the CI(1-0) line which is a good tracer of the diffuse molecular gas. Our primary science goal is to measure the continuum, which drives our RMS request. However, we will also simultaneously observe the CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) lines to obtain information about the diffuse and dense gas content of PSBs. To estimate the intensity of CI(1-0) we estimated the molecular gas mass (6x10^9 Msun) from the stacked dust mass (6x10^7 Msun), assuming a G/D ratio of 100 for our post-starburst galaxies (Rowlands et al. 2015). If the G/D ratio is >110 (expected for PSBs, see Rowlands et al. 2015) then we will detect CO(4-3) at >3 sigma in 100 km/s channels (assuming CO(4-3)/CO(1-0)~0.2, Carilli & Walter 2013).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UDSz45319, UDSz64155 - C36-5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measurement of the continuum, CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) in post-starburst targets 45319 and 64155. These can be observed in the same spectral setup without retuning, and have the same size of ~0.2" so can be observed in the same configuration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary science goal is to observe the continuum in Band 6, we therefore choose the TDM correlator mode with 40 km/s channels. This channel width is also sufficient to observe the CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) lines simultaneously (estimated line width 300 km/s) with the continuum. To achieve adequate signal-to-noise in the lines we will bin up to 100 km/s channels in post processing, which will allow us to detect the CI line at 6 sigma in each channel and CO(4-3) at 3 sigma (if the gas-to-dust ratio >110), with a minimum 3 channels over the line (assuming a line width of 300 km/s). From our high quality optical spectroscopy we anticipate small systematic uncertainties in the velocity of each galaxy of ~100 km/s, however this will not be an issue with our large spectral window width of 2300 km/s. Our correlator set-up yields data rates of 2.44 MB/s which is well within the limits stated in the ALMA technical handbook. We do not have any special requirements on calibration, bandpass accuracy, data rates or scheduling.

The half-light radii of our targets in the rest-frame optical are 0.10-0.12". We therefore expect the dust and gas emission to be on similar scales, with a maximumdiameter of 0.24". We request a resolution of 0.2" (configuation C36-5) so that we will approximately match the extent of our sources. This will allow us to measure the size of the gas and dust emitting region using the uv distance as a function of amplitude (Chen et al. in prep). It is possible that the gas and dust sizes are slightly more or less than the extent of the beam, but the beam size can be tuned using different weightings in CASA. The largest angular scale of our target is 0.24", which is smaller than the maximum resolvable scale of 3.4" in configuration C36-5. We do not require use of the ACA.

Our primary science goal is to detect the rest-frame ~600um dust continuum in our post-starburst galaxies. Our targets are at z~1 so we will observe in Band 6 at ~230 GHz, which allows us to simultaneously observe the CI(1-0) line which is a good tracer of the diffuse molecular gas. The continuum RMS is estimated using a modified blackbody fit to the stacked 24-850um fluxes (with an additional mid-infrared powerlaw for hot dust, Casey 2012) assuming a dust emissivity index of beta=2, kappa=0.077 m^2kg^-1 and a fitted temperature of 25K. At rest-frame 600um the continuum flux density is 0.069mJy, so for a 5 sigma detection using a bandwidth of 7.5 GHz (assuming the source extends over one synthesised beam) we request an RMS of 13.7uJy. Our primary science goal is to measure the continuum, which drives our RMS request. However, we will also simultaneously observe the CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) lines to obtain information about the diffuse and dense gas content of PSBs. To estimate the intensity of CI(1-0) we estimated the molecular gas mass (6x10^9 Msun) from the stacked dust mass (6x10^7 Msun), assuming a G/D ratio of 100 for our post-starburst galaxies (Rowlands et al. 2015). The CI(1-0) line flux was estimated using equation 12 of Papadopoulos et al. (2004), assuming Q_10=0.35, X_CI=3x10^-5 and the Einstein A coefficient A_ul=7.93x10^-8 s^-1 (Papadopoulos & Geach 2012). We assume a line width of 300 km/s, yielding a peak CI line flux of 0.82 mJy. By integrating to the continuum RMS we expect to detect the CI(1-0) at 6 sigma siginificance in 100 km/s channels (assuming 3 channels over an expected line width of 300 km/s). If we do not detect the line this puts a hard upper limit on the molecular gas content of high redshift post-starburst galaxies. If the G/D ratio is >110 (expected for PSBs, see Rowlands et al. 2015) then we will detect CO(4-3) at >3 sigma in 100 km/s channels (assuming CO(4-3)/CO(1-0)~0.2, Carilli & Walter 2013).
We have selected a non-standard continuum frequency in Band 6 so in order to simultaneously observe the continuum, CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) lines for two sources without retuning.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UDSz63906 - C36-4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Measurement of the continuum, CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) emission in post-starburst target 63906, which has a different size (diameter=0.42") to the other sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary science goal is to observe the continuum in Band 6, we therefore choose the TDM correlator mode with 40 km/s channels. This channel width is also sufficient to observe the CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) lines simultaneously (estimated line width 300 km/s) with the continuum. To achieve adequate signal-to-noise in the lines we will bin up to 100 km/s channels in post processing, which will allow us to detect the CI line at 6 sigma in each channel and CO(4-3) at 3 sigma (if the gas-to-dust ratio >110), with a minimum 3 channels over the line (assuming a line width of 300 km/s). From our high quality optical spectroscopy we anticipate small systematic uncertainties in the velocity of each galaxy of ~100 km/s, however this will not be an issue with our large spectral window width of 2300 km/s. Our correlator set-up yields data rates of 2.44 MB/s which is well within the limits stated in the ALMA technical handbook. We do not have any special requirements on calibration, bandpass accuracy, data rates or scheduling.

The half-light radii of our target in the rest-frame optical is 0.21". We therefore expect the dust and gas emission to be on similar scales, with a diameter of 0.42". We request a resolution of 0.3" (configuration C36-4) to approximately match the extent of our sources. This will allow us to measure the size of the gas and dust emitting region using the uv distance as a function of amplitude (Chen et al. in prep). It is possible that the gas and dust sizes are slightly more or less than the extent of the beam, but the beam size can be tuned using different weightings in CASA. The largest angular scale of our target is 0.42", which is smaller than the maximum resolvable scale of 4.2" in configuration C36-4. We do not require use of the ACA.

Our primary science goal is to detect the rest-frame ~600um dust continuum in our post-starburst galaxies. Our targets are at z~1 so we will observe in Band 6 at ~230 GHz, which allows us to simultaneously observe the CI(1-0) line which is a good tracer of the diffuse molecular gas. The continuum RMS is estimated using a modified blackbody fit to the stacked 24-850um fluxes (with an additional mid-infrared powerlaw for hot dust, Casey 2012) assuming a dust emissivity index of beta=2, kappa=0.077 m^2kg^-1 and a fitted temperature of 25K. At rest-frame 600um the continuum flux density is 0.069mJy, so for a 5 sigma detection using a bandwidth of 7.5 GHz (assuming the source extends over one synthesised beam) we request an RMS of 13.7uJy. Our primary science goal is to measure the continuum, which drives our RMS request. However, we will also simultaneously observe the CI(1-0) and CO(4-3) lines to obtain information about the diffuse and dense gas content of PSBs. To estimate the intensity of CI(1-0) we estimated the molecular gas mass (6x10^9 Msun) from the stacked dust mass (6x10^7 Msun), assuming a G/D ratio of 100 for our post-starburst galaxies (Rowlands et al. 2015). The CI(1-0) line flux was estimated using equation 12 of Papadopoulos et al. (2004), assuming Q_10=0.35, X_CI=3x10^-5 and the Einstein A coefficient A_ul=7.93x10^-8 s^-1 (Papadopoulos & Geach 2012). We assume a line width of 300 km/s, yielding a peak CI line flux of 0.82 mJy. By integrating to the continuum RMS we expect to detect the CI(1-0) at 6 sigma siginificance in 100 km/s channels (assuming 3 channels over an expected line width of 300 km/s). If we do not detect the line this puts a hard upper limit on the molecular gas content of high redshift post-starburst galaxies. If the G/D ratio is >110 (expected for PSBs, see Rowlands et al. 2015) then we will detect CO(4-3) at >3 sigma in 100 km/s channels (assuming CO(4-3)/CO(1-0)~0.2, Carilli & Walter 2013).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Understanding why star formation is shut down galaxies is important for understanding their origins, the quenching mechanism, and how rapidly galaxies build up the red-sequence. The stacked far-infrared fluxes of the first robust sample of z~1 post-starburst galaxies reveal a surprising result - that quenching galaxies still harbour a substaintial cold ISM. This finding is at odds with the expectation that these galaxies have run out of gas and will enter the red-sequence in the next few 100 Myr. Using 12 hours of ALMA time we propose a study of the dust and gas properties of 5 massive, ultra-compact z~1 galaxies which are undergoing rapid quenching of their star formation. Our observations will allow us to determine exactly what mechanisms have caused these galaxies to suddenly stop forming stars efficiently, and to examine galaxies in a crucial stage of their evolution between dusty starbursts and compact quiescent galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00057.S, "The hunt for galaxy wide quenching: Measuring gas consumption and expulsion following merger driven starbursts at z~1", PI: Vivienne Wild

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics and Astronomy, St. Andrews, University of
